assumption: Human-AI collaboration roles should be pre-defined and static
hypothesis: Dynamic role allocation based on task phase, confidence levels, and accumulated context produces higher quality research outputs than static role assignments
impact: Changes how we design AI research assistants - from fixed-role tools to adaptive collaborators

assumption: Each collaboration session should start fresh without memory
hypothesis: Accumulated context across sessions accelerates collaboration efficiency and builds stronger human-AI working relationships
impact: Justifies investment in persistent context systems for research AI tools

assumption: More feedback iterations always improve output quality
hypothesis: Quality improvements from iterative feedback plateau after 3-4 rounds, with diminishing returns thereafter
impact: Provides guidance on optimal iteration depth for human-AI writing workflows
